**Patrick's Description** from **#1109**: Currently with the ability to log in with either NEXT creds or corporate AD creds, it seems that I can create a NExt acct that matches my AD acct and get all the privileges tied to my AD creds. While removing the UI switch to allow me to pick NEXT/AD will hide this issue, we really should be more robust about rejecting this on login.

**Patrick's Acceptance-Criteria** from **#1109**: May be tricky to demo this one after we disable radio button on login page -- need to show that a next acct with a different PW than my AD acct doesn't get my AD level of access.

**Steps to be taken**:

1. Identify the POST API that is being called when Create New User (sign up) button is hit. This API will get the new user account creation details including - "username"
2. Also, identify the query that is called to fetch the count of matching users with same as given username in the Rethink Database. If not exists already create this query.
3. Identify a place where sounds logical to be implemented when POST API details are submitted to the corresponding table in database. Because, this is where we shall restrict that new data from being added if the username is NOT UNIQUE.
4. Introduce the error handling there to display - "user already exists" message.
5. Write the test case around this logic, if necessary.
6. Test this modified functionality.
7. If working fine, peer review & make a pull request.

Here is where the ldap syncs stand regarding connections:
  Connection timeouts -  read:10 sec,  connect: 6 sec, retry: 10 sec
  Inital syncs retry/warn every 10 seconds until connected
  Delta inbound opens a new connection for every iteration

There are initial & delta syncs as well as inbound & outbound syncs. The connections can fail in a number of ways for a number of reasons (eg: if auth fails, then there is no point in retrying since the creds come in on the env, so it makes sense to exit completely). 

I am adding a PR that wraps the outbound delta sync in a try/catch for session termination:
https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-next-directory/pull/900

And am going to request that, if we open this defect again, we are specific about which sync fails (initial, delta)(inbound, outbound) and include steps to reproduce what you are experiencing. I would rather avoid wrapping in generic Exception because doing so risks any unrelated Exception causing an endless loop of non-deterministic effect.

We discussed this briefly during an afternoon group review yesterday. A few topics/opinions shared:

Authoring custom assertion types: I've seen it done before. It isn't generally my thing, but when other people do it, it isn't an issue because it usually happens at a time when some folks are writing tests and others are not. Top priority is to get everybody writing tests for their changes regularly.
  - I try to keep assertions minimal and targeted specifically towards the result.
  - Custom assertions run the risk of enforcing aspects of the project that are still evolving. I have seen in the past assertions that expect http status, body, headers... fail when the endpoint changes. 

I try to keep unit tests as minimal/understandable as possible. That said: The details about what constitute well-crafted tests are a topic of opinion: 
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3258733/new-to-unit-testing-how-to-write-great-tests#3258768

Re: Dependencies: Relying on, and importing fixtures for more complex tests is a necessity lest you end up with redundant boilerplate. I prefer to do the lifecycle elements (server spin-up, db ddl, etc) in a "before all tests" step and, if possible, wrap each test in setup/teardown. If that proves to be more effort than using random data for each test object, then random data is preferred using a builder with random defaults and optional attribute overrides as necessary.

We will be utilizing the bind operation in the LDAP protocol (which is part of the ldap3 library that we have been using for LDAP inbound/outbound sync). When a user attempts to login to NEXT, their AD credentials will be passed from the Frontend UI to the `/api/authorization` API endpoint. The endpoint will use the AD credentials and perform the BIND operation where it will attempt to authenticate against the LDAP instance that is connected to NEXT. If the credentials are valid, the bind will be successful, but if the bind fails, the result will return an error message indicating why the operation failed. After a successful bind, a search will be performed in LDAP to get the user's UID (this could be distinguishedName, username, or email as we have not decided what would be the UID). The UID will be stored in a session manager to keep track of the session. After the user logins, the data associated with the UID will be on display.
